questions.question: How important do you think is exploration or total out of the box thinking exploration in this space?
How important is it to explore totally outside of the strategies that have been working for you so far?
How do you make sense if you were to try to disentangle the Marvá paradox?
If you agree, then maybe do you zoom in in some particular aspect of that problem that you just like?
But the source of newness and uncertainty, have you found problems in which it's easy to generate new newnessnessnesses?
So what are, just by the way in the grasping, what are the difficulties that have been worked on?
Why is it such a difficult, why is picking stuff up such a difficult problem?
You have some query like what action do I take in order for X to be true?
But what do you use the fundamental difference between reinforcement learning and maybe supervised machine learning?
Do we need to collect big benchmark data sets that allow us to explore the space?
Or maybe coming together in a space of robotics and defining the right problem to be working on?
And what is your sense of the limits of this representation power and the control context?
To throw a brief wrench into our discussion, let me ask, do you think we're living in a simulation?
Just as a quick aside, what are your thoughts about when the human enters the picture of the robotics problem?
You could say, can we write down kind of a general objective that leads to good capability?
What have you learned about yourself from trying to build robots and reinforcement learning systems?
When did you first yourself fall in love with the idea of artificial intelligence, get captivated by this field?
What are the first steps to take and further on what are the steps to take on that journey?
What do you think, ridiculous, big question, what do you think is the meaning of life?
Now, of course, success is built on top of success and you keep going forever, but what is the dream?
